frameDefinitions: The words in this frame refer to facial Expressions and the Possessors of those Expressions.
This frame contains perception words whose perceivers intentionally direct their attention to some entity or phenomenon in order to have a perceptual experience.
A group of Colonists from a Homeland migrate to and proceed to settle in a New_area.
An Agent makes a particular facial expression, generally in response to some Internal_cause (generally an emotional state).
A physical entity, construed as a point-Sound_source, emits a Sound.

This frame deals with a Speaker communicating a reply or response, a Message, to some prior communication or action, the Trigger.  '' 'The landlord has not yet replied in writing to the tenant objecting the proposed alterations.
frameExamples: In the 7th century BC, Phoenicians <t>colonized</t> the eastern section of Libya.
His eyes <t>smile</t>, but his lips do not.
The landlord has not yet <t>replied</t> in writing to the tenant objecting the proposed alterations.DNI
listRoleDefinitions: This is the <fen>Expression</fen> made.
This is the person who exhibitis the <fen>Expression</fen>.
The emotion that is conveyed by a particular <fen>Expression</fen>.
The <fen>Perceiver_agentive</fen> performs some action in order to have a perceptual experience. It is expressed as an External Argument:

<fen>Phenomenon</fen> indicates the entity or phenomenon to which the <fen>Perceiver_agentive</fen> directs his or her attention in order to have a perceptual experience. Typically, it is expressed as an Object with verbs.
<fen>Body_part</fen> identifies the part of the body used as a sensory organ of the <fen>Perceiver_agentive</fen>, typically expressed in a <ment>with</ment>-PP.

<fen>Direction</fen> is used for all path-like expressions that describe how the perceiver's attention is directed during the act of perception, with the exception of those indicating the location of the <fen>Perceiver_agentive</fen> (which would be marked <fen>Location_of_perceiver</fen>)
When the activity of attempting to perceive occurs.
The general location within which the act of perception takes place.
A group of people who move together to an area outside their <fen>Homeland</fen> for the purpose of settling.
The <fen>Homeland</fen> is where the <fen>Colonists</fen> are originally from.
The <fen>Colonists</fen> move to the <fen>New_area</fen>, inhabiting it and (in the case of nation-states) extending the control of the <fen>Homeland</fen>.
The time at which the colonizing takes place.
The individual that assumes a particular facial expression.
The particular part of the face that the <fen>Agent</fen> moves into a facial expression.
The point in time at which the change in facial_expression takes place.

The frame element <fen>Sound_source</fen> is assigned to a constituent referring to a physical entity which emits a sound. Such an entity must have an appropriately complex internal structure such that it can create a sound. For example, a machine or some other thing with moving parts can create sound by itself.

The frame element <fen>Sound</fen> is incorporated in the meaning of the verbs of this frame. Otherwise, this role is assigned to NPs which actually refer to a sound in the presence of the target. This typically occurs when the target is a verb used as a modifier in its <ment>-ing</ment> form, e.g.:
An event in which one or more <fen>Sound_source</fen>s participate and which is accompanied by <fen>Sound</fen>.
The time when the <fen>Noisy_event</fen> occurs.

The location of the <fen>Sound_source</fen>. This role differs from <fen>Location_of_source</fen> only in terms of point of view; the latter role implies a point of view that is not on the <fen>Sound_source</fen>.

The <fen>Speaker</fen> is the sentient entity that communicates the reply or response. It is expressed as the External Argument of predicative uses of a <t>Target</t> verb or as the Genitive modifier of a <t>Target</t> noun:
This is the person to whom the response is communicated.  When expressed, this role occurs as the direct object of a <t>Target</t> verb, or in a prepositional phrase introduced by 'to':
The <fen>Message</fen> is the role that identifies the content of what the <fen>Speaker</fen> is communicating to the <fen>Addressee</fen>. It can be expressed as a direct quote or a clause.
<fen>Topic</fen> occurs quite rarely in this frame and usually only as a PP Complement of a noun <t>Target</t>:
The <fen>Trigger</fen> is the prior communication or action to which a response is given. It can occur as an NP Object or a PP Complement.
The time interval during which the <fen>Speaker</fen> makes their verbal response.
The location in which the <fen>Speaker</fen>  makes a verbal response.
listRoleExamples: <fex>The waiter</fex> smelled the milk to see if it was fresh.
The waiter smelled <fex>the milk</fex> to see if it was fresh.
You should feel the water <fex>with your toes</fex> before jumping in.
The detective looked <fex>across the street</fex> at the suspect.
<fex>Spain</fex> settled the northern areas of Mexico through the use of missions, civil settlements, and presidios.
Norse invaders in the 900s colonized <fex>the North Midlands</fex> more densely than any other part of England'
It's going to beep again <fex>in two minutes</fex>.
My boss still hasn't given me an answer <fex>about a promotion</fex>.
A reminder letter was sent to all nonrespondents who had not replied <fex>after 28 days</fex>.
This was how Tamil Nadu Chief Minister Jayalalithaa responded <fex>in the Assembly</fex> on November 5, 2003.
